p: In the case of RO, the EO was able to inhibit the growth of A. baumannii at concentrations of 500 μg/mL but was unable to inhibit the growth of the rest of the bacterial strains tested ( Table 1). Interestingly, other studies have reported antibacterial activities against E. coli, P. aeruginosa, and S. aureus, with variable MICs ranging between 0.3 mg/mL and 1.72 mg/mL [ 35– 37], which include our MIC of 0.5 mg/mL for A. baumannii. The different chemotypes of the RO EOs used in the different studies may suggest the reason why no activities against E. coli, P. aeruginosa, and S. aureus were observed in our study with concentrations < 2 mg/mL.
